title: Notes of 「Learning Unsupervised Video Object Segmentation through Visual Attention」
content:
paper: http://www.dabi.temple.edu/~hbling/publication/UVOS-cvpr19.pdf

What is UVOS

Unsupervised Video Object Segmentation (UVOS): automatically segmenting primary object regions from the background in videos.

Motivation

During visual perception, humans are able to quickly orient attentions to the most important parts of the visual stimuli, allowing them to achieve goals efficiently.

Therefore here comes the hypothesis: human visual attention should be the underlying mechanism that drives UVOS.

The foreground in UVOS should be the object(s) that attracts human attention most, as the choice of the object(s) should be consistent with human attention judgements.

In-depth Data Analysis

To validate the hypothesis, the authors extend 3 video segmentation datasets, Davis16, Youtube-Objects and SegTrackV2, with real human fixation annotation.

Inter-subject consistency (ISC)

ISC is eye movement consistency with subjects. According to The Secrets of Salient Object Segmentation, ISC is the similarity between the fixation task and the salient segmentation task, computed by AUC score or F-measure.

  • Fixation task
    1. Plot all the fixation points
    2. Filter the saliency map by a 2D Gaussian kernel with of the image width
  • Salient segmentation task
    1. Averaging the individual segmentations
    2. Threshold with to generate the binary masks

Inter-task consistency (ITC)

ITC is to study whether human visual attention and video primary object judgement agree with each other. According to What stands out in a scene? A study of human explicit saliency judgment and this paper, ITC is computed as follows:

  • Human fixations are considered as the positive set and some points sampled from other non-fixation positions as the negative set
  • The segmentation mask is then used as a binary classifier to separate positive samples from negative samples
  • Compute AUC-Juddy

Observation

  • There exist highly consistent attention behaviors among human observers in the UVOS task, though the notion of ‘primary object(s)’ is sometimes viewed as ill-posed for extremely-diverse dynamic scenes.
  • There exists a strong correlation between human fixation and human explicit judgement of primary object(s).

Method

Roughly speaking, visual attention acts as a middle-level representation that bridges dynamic foreground characteristic modeling and static attention-aware object segmentation.

Inspired by these findings, the authors decouple UVOS into two sub-tasks: UVOS-driven Dynamic Visual Attention Prediction (DVAP) in spatiotemporal domain, and Attention-Guided Object Segmentation (AGOS) in spatial domain.

Such design naturally reflects realworld human behavior, i.e., first orienting rough attention to important areas during dynamic viewing, and then focusing on fine-grained, pixel-wise object segmentation.

Therefore, the problem is defined as:

DVAP Module

AGOS Module

For the position with an attention value close to 0, the corresponding feature response will be suppressed greatly. This may lose some meaningful information. A residual operation is adopted here.

Loss

For DAVP, given an input frame , it predicts an attention map . is a discrete map, recording whether a pixel receives human-eye fixation positon. is obtained by blurring with a small Gaussian filter.
